posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked:
We’ve always used ‘flip down’ style intakes.  We did one 4-bar style intake, but it was chain driven and static so that when it was impacted it didn’t fold up.

I’m wondering - what’s the drive mechanism people use to allow a 4-bar style intake to fold up when hit, but still be able to verify when it’s down or up.

Here’s a screen shot of Poofs in 2022.  Their intake was constantly hitting walls and other robots and folding up without damage.  How do you actuate something like this with motors, but allow it to fold?

image 819×511 53.2 KB

image 819×511 53.2 KB

image 819×511 53.2 KB

My initial throught would be to spring it down, and use something like one way bearings and chain to actuate it up.  But I don’t think that’s how the better teams are doing it.

posts.name: Alex Richards
posts.cooked:
Tom_Line:

I’m wondering - what’s the drive mechanism people use to allow a 4-bar style intake to fold up when hit, but still be able to verify when it’s down or up.

In this specific example, I’m pretty sure 254 used pneumatics, which would have actuated the mechanism back to the deployed state even after being forced back into a collapsed state.

A good example might be to look at 1678’s robot from Rapid React, which I believe used a motorized pivot. Their system seemed to have a good amount of compliance built in, so they might not have had to compensate for the driven link being back driven.

posts.name: Ian Saam
posts.cooked: Similar to how people use current detection to detect if a game piece is in their manipulator, I’d reason to guess that you can use current sensing on the pivot motor while it has pid enabled to stay in the “out” position, and then once the current goes above a certain threshold the robot detects that something’s pressing back on the intake and can pull it in automatically? Although if you are just running the intake into a hard stop when it’s out that could get more tricky…

posts.name: Brad
posts.cooked: You can use encoder position to know the state of your intake (up or down).  You can use some gain scheduling to handle your deployment and squish allowance.  Use a regular PID to deploy , if the deployed state can rest on a bumper or stope even better.  then switch to an over dampened PID so when it is hit it folds back up then pushes back out when the force is released.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
Once the intake is down you can just have a small current limit with your controls if you want the motor to be the “spring” (provided your gear reductions are not a weak point).

However, likely more important here IMO is to draw out the free body diagram to see how much back drive force you will see from running into things. The “high pivot” 4-bars we saw in 2022 were easier to back drive when run into a wall because of how the forces passed through. Other 4 bars may be better candidates for compliant or “stretchy” links. Ideally you want to avoid relying on back-driving to protect your intake if forces will be anywhere near the overcentering point of the mechanism.

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked:
My issue with using current sensing to do this is a couple fold.  First - if I’m actuating this thing quickly, pretty often it’s broken before the feedback of “too much current” is back and I can make a decision.  Second - I hate fixing what I think is a mechanical problem in code.

Fixing this issue in code is possible, but seems wrong to me:  this is primarily mechanical problem that feels like it should be addressed with design.  Pneumatics is the easy way, but most people have removed pneumatics now and it seems like and elegant motor solution would be out there somewhere.

I suppose some type of friction clutch would work as well - a couple pieces of stacked polycarb tensioned together, etc.  Perhaps if you sprung the intake down, and pulled up with some dyneema.

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: Using the motor as a spring works well. It’s an elegant solution. Can’t get much less part count than zero.

posts.name: UnofficialForth
posts.cooked:
Tom_Line:

My issue with using current sensing to do this is a couple fold…

I think you misunderstood. You set a low current limit so that the intake folds back in on itself when a force acts upon it. The super low current limit allows any hit to “overpower” the motor so it folds in.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FRC Team 4272  Mentor | World's FLL Emcee

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked:
I think the description by @Enjsnake inserts this confusion a little.

With a low hold current in the out position you don’t need to actively retract your mechanism, the force acting on it does this for you overpowering the motor as you describe.

When the force is removed it pops back out. Once setup correctly and position set, there are no decisions or active actions taking place, the mechanism is structured to behave compliantly, passively.
Just wondering, will setting the motor’s neutral mode to coast when it is deployed work?

posts.name: Henrique Schmitz
posts.cooked:
Tom_Line:

My issue with using current sensing to do this is a couple fold. First - if I’m actuating this thing quickly, pretty often it’s broken before the feedback of “too much current” is back and I can make a decision. Second - I hate fixing what I think is a mechanical problem in code.

I believe the best way to think about this feature is an additional line of defense. You should build your intake thinking it won’t collapse and should be able to take the hits nevertheless. In 2024 we had a pivoting intake that wouldn’t collapse and didn’t have too many issues as it was, even though we did smash it against the walls a bit.

For the 4 bar collapsing, the motion direction itself is your largest ally here. The more horizontal your movement direction is, the better. This way the forces would just be actuating directly against whatever is on the other side and then you can tune it to put as much spring force into resisting the movement as you find best. For sure you want at least some force keeping it open, gravity will do in a static environment, but with dynamic robot movement I would wager having something keeping it from bobbing up and down is good.

The main concern related to what is keeping the intake open are how strong it is (should be tunable ideally) and how linear it is. I would guess that pneumatics are probably the worst option since they would start putting up little effort (since the force of the cylinder would be a bit more radial on the arm pivot) and increase as you collapse in (as it gets more tangential). A motor should behave linearly (at least mechanically, not sure how the force the motor makes would vary because of the electrical effects off the top of my head). One good candidate is a spring / elastic pulling the 4-bar down/forward. In this case you would have a stronger force keeping it in place and avoiding small movements, but as the arms move inwards it can start being less effective and just allowing the intake to collapse as much as it needs if the force threshold has been breached.

As for using the motor as a spring, I would probably favor applying a small voltage to it constantly instead of a current limit. Low current limits could block your intake from opening/closing as fast as your motor is capable of. You could change the current limit for when it is supposed to move and when it is supposed to stay open, but changing this kind of config is normally a bit of a slower process on the controller and not something you want to be doing all the time mid match. Even just turning the motor off if it is open isn’t a terrible idea, but would just lead to a bit more bobbing.

posts.name: Henrique Schmitz
posts.cooked:
TheBatman:

Just wondering, will setting the motor’s neutral mode to coast when it is deployed work?

If you are not running a PID or too strong of a voltage keeping it open, yes. If you have a PID , that will resist the movement nevertheless. But like I said on the previous reply, maybe just keep it in coast all the time and hold it up with PID then.

posts.name: Yair Kornblau
posts.cooked:
This. The only thing that you need to keep in mind is to have the contact point with the wall above your main axis of rotation for the “driving” arm of the geometry, to make it fold “up” instead of “down” and getting stuck. (on our 2022 1678 copycat intake we made the front axis movement entirely linear which is even better). Edit: as long as the lower axis point on the front portion of the four bar is above that arm’s rotation point, you’ll have a collapsing mechanism. Limiting current and putting in a pretty fast gear ratio works well. I’s what we did on Whisper and it worked out great. One of the only intakes we ever built that didn’t need any maintenance to work.

Google Drive file.

posts.name: Henrique Schmitz
posts.cooked:
Korny:

Limiting current and putting in a pretty fast gear ratio works well. I’s what we did on Whisper and it worked out great.

To keep it open, were you guys running a PID , relying on gravity, applying a small voltage or something else?

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked:
So - doesn’t limiting current in that way really slow down the motion of putting the intake out?

Also - it looks like your intake linkage is directly in line with the collision.  Is the reason the intake pops up because your rollers hit the wall and lift it?

Our intakes have somewhat heavy in the past, and I’ve always thought generally more current = more power / speed.

posts.name: Jon Stratis
posts.cooked:
Tom_Line:

I suppose some type of friction clutch would work as well - a couple pieces of stacked polycarb tensioned together, etc. Perhaps if you sprung the intake down, and pulled up with some dyneema.

We built our own friction clutch one year, details and pictures here:

"Give a little" - keeping mechanisms from exploding on impact Technical

It was strong enough to lift the intake to the desired position, yet let you push it in manually - because of the encoder on the shaft, the intake would just pop right back out with the pid control.  If the intake was stuck in for any reason, the clutch would slip and the motor wouldn’t burn out.

This sort of thing definitely can work, depending on the relative weight/resistance in the intake/arm.  Since it relies on friction, trying to lift a heavier arm with it may cause it to slip before it gets to the desired location, so it’s not a one-size-fits-all solution.

link_counts.title: "Give a little" - keeping mechanisms from exploding on impact

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
Serial elastics are another valid option here, as you alluded to with the linked thread.

You can do a lot with studs and springs.

I’m gonna stick my my guns that the geometry of the 4 bar is the starting point and not how you are powering it. Running a force perfectly in line down a link directly into a robot frame will never result in a collapsible intake.

posts.name: Andrew McBride
posts.cooked:
Tom_Line:

So - doesn’t limiting current in that way really slow down the motion of putting the intake out?

You can update current limits during usage, so during motion you set the current limit higher than it would be during a hold position. Say 80A limit while lifting or lowering the intake, but to hold position while out it is a 10-15A limit.

posts.name: Yair Kornblau
posts.cooked:
Tom_Line:

So - doesn’t limiting current in that way really slow down the motion of putting the intake out?

Not really as long as you still have enough torque to move the system. We had surgical tubing that helps lift it up.

Tom_Line:

Also - it looks like your intake linkage is directly in line with the collision. Is the reason the intake pops up because your rollers hit the wall and lift it?

They’re not really in line, the main axis of rotation is below the bottom “front” axis point point on the arm and creates an angle of less than 180, which makes it pop up. While it is an earlier version (more rollers), the concept remained the same: Screenshot_20250508_205055_WhatsApp 893×1396 139 KB

Screenshot_20250508_205055_WhatsApp 893×1396 139 KB

Screenshot_20250508_205055_WhatsApp 893×1396 139 KB
